title: How do you monitor application performance across different cloud providers in a multi-cloud environment?

content:
A multi-cloud environment refers to enterprises using multiple cloud platforms (such as AWS, Azure, GCP) to enhance flexibility and disaster recovery capabilities. Monitoring application performance ensures high availability, identifies bottlenecks, and optimizes resource costs, applicable to globally distributed applications and hybrid cloud deployment scenarios.

Core components include cross-cloud data collection tools (such as Prometheus agents), centralized platforms (such as Grafana or Datadog), utilizing APIs to standardize metrics and log ingestion. This provides a unified view, enabling real-time insights, accelerating fault response, and reducing operational complexity and downtime.

Implementation steps: 1. Deploy lightweight agents in each cloud application to collect performance data. 2. Integrate into a unified monitoring system and set up alerts. 3. Visualize key metrics such as latency and error rates on dashboards. A typical scenario is tracking microservice call chains; business values include improving reliability, reducing risks, and supporting cost optimization.
